security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only markdown documentation for using glab CLI. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access beyond documentation. The file provides legitimate instructions for GitLab operations.

content.user_title: Manage GitLab issues and merge requests
content.value_statement: Managing GitLab issues and merge requests manually takes time and risks inconsistent formatting. This skill provides standardized commands to view, create, and update GitLab MRs and issues non-interactively through the glab CLI tool.
actual_capabilities: View GitLab issues with or without comments
View merge request details, diffs, and related issues
Create merge requests with standardized formatting
Create issues with title and multi-line descriptions
Update existing MRs and issues non-interactively
Add comments to issues and merge requests
limitations: Requires glab CLI tool to be installed and authenticated
Cannot operate on GitLab without network access to the instance
Does not create or modify code files directly
Limited to GitLab platform operations only

use_cases.title: Streamline MR creation workflow
use_cases.description: Create merge requests with consistent formatting and proper description templates following team conventions

use_cases.title: Automate GitLab operations
use_cases.description: View issue discussions, update MR status, and track changes across multiple projects from command line

use_cases.title: Track project issues efficiently
use_cases.description: List open issues, view their status, and add comments without leaving the terminal

prompt_templates.title: View issue
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me issue #123 including all comments

prompt_templates.title: View MR diff
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the diff for merge request 456 and who authored it

prompt_templates.title: Create MR
prompt_templates.scenario: Create a merge request following team standards
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a merge request from current branch feature/login to main branch with semantic title and standardized description

prompt_templates.title: Create issue
prompt_templates.scenario: Create an issue with structured format
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an issue in group/myproject with title about API timeout bug and description explaining expected vs actual behavior

output_examples.input: Show me merge request 42 with its diff
output: MR #42: feat(auth): Add OAuth2 login support
State: opened | Author: developer | Web URL: https://gitlab.example.com/group/project/-/merge_requests/42
View full diff: glab mr diff 42 --color=never

best_practices: Verify glab authentication with glab auth status before operations
Use --output json flag for machine-readable results in scripts
Always pull current title and description before updating existing MRs
Use heredoc syntax for multi-line descriptions to avoid shell issues
anti_patterns: Manually editing MR descriptions in interactive mode instead of using heredoc
Creating MRs without checking git status for clean working directory
Using non-semantic commit prefixes that do not follow conventional commits
Skipping the --yes flag and expecting non-interactive behavior

faq.question: What GitLab instances are supported?
faq.answer: Works with gitlab.com and self-hosted GitLab instances. Use GITLAB_HOST environment variable for self-hosted servers.

faq.question: What are the rate limits for API calls?
faq.answer: Rate limits depend on your GitLab instance configuration. The skill uses glab which respects these limits.

faq.question: How do I integrate this with CI/CD pipelines?
faq.answer: Use glab in scripts with --output json flag. Requires glab authentication via environment variables or configured locally.

faq.question: Is my data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: No. All operations go directly to your configured GitLab instance. The skill itself makes no external network calls.

faq.question: What if glab is not installed?
faq.answer: Install glab from https://github.com/profclems/glab or via package manager. Then run glab auth login to configure credentials.

faq.question: How does this compare to GitLab web interface?
faq.answer: Provides faster CLI workflow, consistent templates, scriptable operations, and works in terminal without browser.
